prompt.p: Normal red cells live for around 120 days, showing signs of age towards the end of this time.
What is the fate of an old red cell?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: ATP levels decrease and glycolysis slows down
Make their way towards the liver for engulfment

modalFeedback.p: Option A (ATP levels decrease and glycolysis slows down) is Correct. The fate of red cells as they age is:

ul.li: antibodies are produced against neoantigens (new antigens) that have been revealed by ageing.

modalFeedback.p:
Senescent red cells are phagocytized and digested by macrophages in the spleen.
Option B (Become more flaccid) is Incorrect. Red cells become more rigid as they age.
Option C (Engulfed by neutrophils) is Incorrect. Senescent red cells are phagocytized by macrophages.
Option D (Make their way towards the liver for engulfment) is Incorrect. Senescent red cells make their way towards the spleen (the graveyard of red cells).
Option E (Membrane lipid levels rise) is Incorrect. Membrane lipid levels reduce as red cells age.
